title-group.article-title: Grammar and Rhetoric in Wordsworth's "A Slumber Did My Spirit Seal": Heidegger, de Man, Deconstruction

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1997 The Trustees of Boston University

p.mixed-citation: Heidegger come, respectively, from "Das Ding," Vorträge und Aufsätze, vol. 2. (Pfullingen: Günther Neske Verlag, 1954, 1967) 51.
"The
Thing," in Poetry, Language, Thought, tr. Albert Hofstadter (New York: Harper & Row, 1971) 178-79.
Unterwegs zur Sprache (Pfullingen: Günther Neske Verlag, 1957) 215.
On the Way to Language, tr. Peter D. Hertz (New York: Harper & Row, 1971) 107.
Helen Darbishire is cited from The Poet Wordsworth (Oxford: Clarendon, 1950) 171.
Wordsworth's poems are cited from The Poems, ed. John O. Hayden, (New Haven and London: Yale UP, 1981).
The Poetical Works of William Wordsworth, ed. Ernest de Selincourt and Helen Darbishire, 5 vols. (Oxford: Clarendon, 1940-54).
E. D. Hirsch, Jr. Validity in Interpretation (New Haven and London: Yale UP, 1967, 1979) 228.
M. H. Abrams, "Construing and Deconstructing," in Doing Things with Texts: Essays in Criticism and Critical Theory, ed. Michael Fischer (New York and London: Norton, 1989).
Frances Ferguson, Wordsworth: Language As Counter-Spirit (New Haven and London: Yale UP, 1977).
J. Hillis Miller, "On edge; the crossways of contemporary criticism," in Theory Now and Then (Durham: Duke UP, 1991).
Romantidsm and Contemporary Criticism, ed. Morris Eaves and Michael Fischer (Ithaca and London: Cornell UP, 1986).
Martin Heidegger, Sein und Zeit. Unveränderter Nachdruck der fünfzehnten, an Hand der Gesamtausgabe durchgesehenen Auflage (Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag, 1986).
Being and Time, tr. John Macquarrie & Edward Robinson (Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1962, 1973) 165. Henceforth cited in the text as BT.
Giorgio Agamben in his U linguaggio e la morte: Un seminario sul luogo délia negatività (Turin: Einaudi, 1982).
Language and Death: The Place of Negativity, tr. Karen E. Pinkus with Michael Hardt (Minneapolis: U of Minnesota P, 1991).
Paul de Man, Blindness and Insight: Essays in the Rhetoric of Contemporary Criticism, 2nd ed. (Minneapolis: U of Minnesota P, 1983) 223-26. Henceforth BI.

de Man's later considerations of the relation between grammar and rhetoric in "Semiology and Rhetoric," Allegories of Reading: Figurai Language in Rousseau, Nietzsche, Rilke, and Proust (New Haven and London: Yale UP, 1979) 7—10
"The Resistance to Theory," The Resistance to Theory (Minneapolis: U of Minnesota P, 1986) 13-17.

Frances Ferguson, for example, has wondered whether the poet does not make a category mistake in seeing the poem's subject "she" as a human being: "... Lucy appears distant inasmuch as she appears to participate in a different order of being from that of the speaker ..." (175).

Miller, however, only takes passing notice of Heidegger's possible relevance to the poem by remarking that "perhaps in response to a deep necessity, Heidegger gives almost the same list of mere things as Wordsworth" (179).
Miller had quoted Heidegger: "Only a stone, a clod of earth, a piece of wood are for us such mere things."
Walter Benjamin, Ursprung des deutschen Trauerspiels, in Gesammelte Schriften, ed. Rolf Tiedemann & Hermann Schweppenhäuser (Frankfurt: Suhrkamp, 1980) 1: 406.
The Origin of German Tragic Drama, tr. John Osborne (London: New Left Books, 1977) 233.
de Man's definition of allegory in "The Rhetoric of Temporality"
Geoffrey Hartman, Wordsworth's Poetry, 1787-1814 (New Haven and London: Yale UP, 1971) 158.
Heidegger, Poetry, Language, Thought, 176 (Vorträge und Aufsätze 2: 48-49).
Heidegger's analysis of "Dasein" in Being and Time.
J. Hillis Miller's connection of her name to "the loss of the logos" (183).
Albert Cook, Thresholds: Studies in the Romantic Experience [Madison: U of Wisconsin P, 1985] 19-20
Vorträage und Aufsätze 2: 51
Poetry, Language, Thought 178-79
Martin Heidegger, "Was ist Metaphysik," Wegmarken (Frankfurt: Vittorio Klos- termann, 1967) 9.
"What is Metaphysics," Basic Writings, ed. David Farrell Krell (New York: Harper & Row, 1977) 103.
Rodolphe Gasché, The Tain of the Mirror: Derrida and the Philosophy of Reflection (Cambridge and London: Harvard UP, 1986)
Emmanuel Lévinas in "La Trace," Humanisme de l'autre homme (MontpeUier: Fata Morgana, 1972) 57-63.
Paul Ricoeur, Time and Narrative, tr. Kathleen Blarney and David Pellauer (Chicago and London: U of Chicago P, 1988) 3: 124-26.
The Will to Power, not given by Miller, is entry #479.
The Will to Power, ed. Walter Kaufinann; tr. W. Kaufmann & R. J. Hollingdale (New York: Random House, 1967) 266.
Friedrich Nietzsche, Werke, ed. Karl Schlechta (Frankfurt am Main, Berlin, Vienna: Ullstein, 1969) 4: 805.
De Man discusses this same text in terms of a rhetoric of "substitutive reversals" of cause for effect, of early for late, of outside for inside, in Allegories of Reading 107-9.
de Man's discussion of the law of non-contradiction and rhetoric in Nietzsche in Allegories of Reading 119-31.

Agamben on the function of the pronoun in medieval grammatical thought: "Inasmuch as it contains both a particular mode of signification and an indicative act, the pronoun is that part of speech in which the passage from signifying to demonstrating is enacted: pure being, the substantia indeterminata that it signifies and that, as such, is not in itself signifiable or definable, becomes signifiable and determinable through an act of 'indi- cation'" (31/22).
